repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Semarang Surakarta Urban
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
While the assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability is unlikely, mostly due to lack
            of local governments' commitment to ensure sufficient
            allocation to operation and maintenance costs, and,
            institutional development impacts are only modest. Lessons
            address two main issues: 1) The integrated approach is not
            always appropriate for large cities, and the absence of a
            firm sector policy framework can inhibit success. Although
            water and sanitation components were traditionally included
            in integrated urban infrastructure development projects,
            projects designed prior to this operation, included
            relatively simple subprojects, where the lack of sector
            policy direction, did not inhibit implementation; but, this
            project covered water and sanitation that required
            significant policy direction, and the Bank supports the
            recommendation by the Operations Evaluation Department, that
            large water and sanitation components be linked to policy
            reform. Thus when considering the use of an integrated urban
            approach, the size of the city should be considered,
            particularly if addressing sectors that do not have a clear
            policy framework. 2) The new paradigm of democracy under the
            new government, the decentralized, autonomous local
            governments, and the financial crisis of 1997-98, led to
            tremendous delays, mostly attributable to the quality of
            leadership at the highest level of local government.
            Therefore, when considering decentralized projects, it is
            paramount to have commitments at the highest level of local
            government, including those of the coordinating, and
            implementing units.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Second Jabotabek Urban
            Development Project and the Semarang-Surakarta Urban
            Development Project and the Water Supply and Sanitation
            Project for Low-Income Communities Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The three audits represent OED's
            effort to broaden its customary project audit format to
            include an analysis of the adequacy of the World Bank's
            sector assistance. Besides analyzing each project, the
            cluster audit identifies constraints and recipes for success
            that could apply to the entire Indonesian water supply and
            sewerage sector. The performance audit report demonstrates
            that the focus of future assistance should aim at creating
            appropriate sector legislation, regulation, and policies.
            Such a policy-based assistance strategy would improve the
            development and impact of future lending and reach the
            smaller municipalities where the needs are the greatest. OED
            rates the Second Jabotabek Urban Development Project
            satisfactory, its institutional development impact modest,
            sustainability unlikely, and both Bank and Borrowr
            performance satisfactory. The rating of the
            Semarang-Surakarta Urban Development Project is problematic
            since the two project cities differed widely in all aspects.
            In the weighted summary rating, OED rates the outcome of the
            Semarang-Surakarta project moderately unsatisfactory, its
            institutional development impact modest, sustainability
            unlikely, Bank performance satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance unsatisfactory. Finally, OED rates the outcome
            of the Water Supply and Sanitation in Low-Income Communities
            project satisfactory, its institutional development impact
            substantial, sustainability likely, and both Bank and
            Borrower performances satisfactory.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Semarang - Surakarta Urban
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the Semarang
            Surakarta urban Development Project are to: a) improve the
            provision of urban infrastructure and services and the
            efficiency of urban investments; b) promote stronger, more
            autonomous, and financially more independent municipal
            governments; and c) contribute towards urban poverty
            alleviation, mainly through better access to essential
            services and an improved urban environment. The project will
            finance priority investments in Semarang and in Surakarta
            in: 1) urban roads and transport; 2) water supply and
            distribution systems; 3) storm drainage and flood control;
            4) solid waste collection and disposal; 5) human waste
            disposal (sewerage and on-site sanitation facilities); 6)
            multi-sectoral programs for kampung (low income area)
            improvements and market improvements, and 7) programs for
            the development and strengthening of local institutions, 8)
            programs to increase local revenue generation; and 9)
            technical assistance for implementation.

Indonesia - Semarang - Surakarta Urban

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - SSUDP Semarang-Surakarta Urban
            Development Project : appraisal & implementation support
            : environmental assessment summary

abstracts.cdata!:
Environmental impacts of the project
            have been identified at the various stages of project
            implementation from planning through to commissioning and
            operation and maintenance.  Impacts have been presented in
            the Preliminary Environmental Assessment (PIL) reports in
            the form of matrices of impact on the physical, biological
            and sociological environment against project activities.
            The SSUDP project is expected to have a positive overall
            impact on the environment.  It will provide a clean water
            supply to many families, reduce the non-sanitary disposal of
            human and solid wastes, decrease flooding and improve the
            living environment especially in the low income residential
            areas.  Negative impacts of the project such as noise, dust
            emission, socio-economic problems and traffic disruption
            during the construction phase are minor and relatively short
            term.  No land use changes of significance will result from
            project implementation.  Land acquisition requirements of
            the project are relatively small and will not create undue
            social hardship except for the drainage and the urban roands project.

docna.cdata!:
Indonesia - SSUDP Semarang-Surakarta Urban
            Development Project : appraisal & implementation support
            : environmental assessment summary
